question.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the oxygen dissociation curve to the right?

solution.text: Oxygen binds with hemoglobin in a reversible manner to form oxyhemoglobin. A maximum of four oxygen molecules is carried by each Hb. The binding of oxygen is related to the partial pressure of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> whereas partial pressure of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>, hydrogen ion concentration, and temperature are factors interfering with its binding. The factors which are favorable for formation of oxyhemoglobin in the alveoli are high <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>, lesser <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> concentration, low <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2,</mn></mrow></msub></math> and lower temperature. These conditions shift the oxygen dissociation curve to the left. The low <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>, high <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>, high <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> concentration, and higher temperature in the tissues are all the conditions leading to dissociation of oxygen from the oxyhemoglobin. These conditions shift the oxygen dissociation curve to the right.
